title: Psalms Chapter 79 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 79 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 79 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 79.

questions.question: Who are said to have come into God's inheritance according to Psalms 79:1?
options: The heathen
The angels
The prophets
The kings
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:1 states, 'O God, the heathen are come into thine inheritance.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 79:2, what were the dead bodies of God's servants given to?
options: Meat unto the fowls of the heaven
Burial in the ground
Burning with fire
Thrown into the sea
questions.correctAnswer: Meat unto the fowls of the heaven
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:2 says, 'The dead bodies of thy servants have they given to be meat unto the fowls of the heaven.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 79:3 say was shed like water round about Jerusalem?
options: Their blood
Their tears
Their prayers
Their gold
questions.correctAnswer: Their blood
questions.explanation: According to Psalms 79:3, 'Their blood have they shed like water round about Jerusalem.'

questions.question: In Psalms 79:4, how are the people described in relation to their neighbours?
options: A reproach, a scorn and derision
Beloved and honored
Feared and respected
Unknown and ignored
questions.correctAnswer: A reproach, a scorn and derision
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:4 says, 'We are become a reproach to our neighbours, a scorn and derision to them that are round about us.'

questions.question: What question does the Psalmist ask God in Psalms 79:5?
options: How long wilt thou be angry for ever?
Where is thy mercy?
Why did you create us?
When will peace come?
questions.correctAnswer: How long wilt thou be angry for ever?
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:5 includes the question, 'How long, LORD? wilt thou be angry for ever?'

questions.question: According to Psalms 79:6, upon whom does the Psalmist ask God to pour out His wrath?
options: The heathen and kingdoms that have not called upon His name
The priests and Levites
The prophets
The chosen people
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen and kingdoms that have not called upon His name
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:6 states, 'Pour out thy wrath upon the heathen that have not known thee, and upon the kingdoms that have not called upon thy name.'

questions.question: What have the enemies done to Jacob, according to Psalms 79:7?
options: Devoured him and laid waste his dwelling place
Blessed him abundantly
Protected his land
Ignored him completely
questions.correctAnswer: Devoured him and laid waste his dwelling place
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:7 says, 'For they have devoured Jacob, and laid waste his dwelling place.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 79:8 ask God to remember not against the people?
options: Former iniquities
Their enemies' sins
Their wealth
Their victories
questions.correctAnswer: Former iniquities
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:8 requests, 'O remember not against us former iniquities.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 79:9: 'Help us, O God of our _______, for the glory of thy name.'
options: salvation
peace
strength
mercy
questions.correctAnswer: salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:9 says, 'Help us, O God of our salvation, for the glory of thy name.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 79:10, what do the heathen say?
options: Where is their God?
God is with them
They have many gods
God is all-powerful
questions.correctAnswer: Where is their God?
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:10 says, 'Wherefore should the heathen say, Where is their God?'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 79:11 asks God to preserve those that are appointed to die.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:11 states, 'preserve thou those that are appointed to die.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 79:12 say should be returned to the neighbours for their reproach?
options: Sevenfold into their bosom
Forgiveness and peace
Gold and silver
A single warning
questions.correctAnswer: Sevenfold into their bosom
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:12 says, 'And render unto our neighbours sevenfold into their bosom their reproach.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 79:13, who will give thanks and show forth praise to all generations?
options: The people and sheep of God's pasture
The heathen
The kings of the earth
The angels
questions.correctAnswer: The people and sheep of God's pasture
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:13 states, 'So we thy people and sheep of thy pasture will give thee thanks for ever.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 79:3 mentions that there was none to bury the dead bodies around Jerusalem.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:3 states, 'and there was none to bury them.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 79:1 says that Jerusalem was preserved and peaceful.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:1 says Jerusalem was laid on heaps and the temple defiled, indicating destruction, not peace.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 79 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 79 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 79, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God during times of suffering?
options: God’s mercy can quickly rescue those who are brought very low.
God ignores the cries of those who suffer.
Suffering means God has abandoned His people.
Only human effort can bring deliverance in trials.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s mercy can quickly rescue those who are brought very low.
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:8 speaks of God's tender mercies that speedily prevent us when we are brought very low. This assures believers that God is compassionate and ready to help in times of distress. Verses 9 and 11 also encourage calling upon God for salvation and preservation in trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 79 teach us about humility and repentance in the face of sin and judgment?
options: We should ask God to remember not our former iniquities and seek His forgiveness.
We should justify our sins and blame others.
Repentance is unnecessary if we suffer punishment.
God punishes without mercy regardless of repentance.
questions.correctAnswer: We should ask God to remember not our former iniquities and seek His forgiveness.
questions.explanation: In Psalms 79:8-9, the psalmist pleads for God not to remember former sins and asks for deliverance and cleansing for His name’s sake. This shows the importance of humble repentance as a pathway to restoration. Verses 5 and 6 also acknowledge God’s righteous anger but invite His mercy.

questions.question: A church member feels discouraged because others mock their faith. What encouragement does Psalms 79 provide about enduring scorn from neighbors?
options: The people of God may be a reproach and derision to neighbors, but God hears their sighs and will vindicate them.
Believers should avoid all confrontation with neighbors.
Mockery means God has rejected the believer.
We should respond with anger and revenge immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: The people of God may be a reproach and derision to neighbors, but God hears their sighs and will vindicate them.
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:4 acknowledges being a reproach and scorn to neighbors, but verses 10 and 11 ask God to be known among the heathen and to hear the sighing of prisoners, promising vindication. This encourages perseverance through ridicule with trust in God’s justice.

questions.question: What biblical principle about prayer and dependence on God in times of national crisis is emphasized in Psalms 79?
options: Praying earnestly for God’s intervention and cleansing is essential for deliverance.
God will save without the need for prayer.
National crises should be handled only by political means.
Prayer is irrelevant when enemies prevail.
questions.correctAnswer: Praying earnestly for God’s intervention and cleansing is essential for deliverance.
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:9 calls God to help and deliver for His name’s glory and to purge away sins. The psalm demonstrates the importance of heartfelt prayer and dependence on God in times of trouble, supported by verses 6 and 8 which plead for God’s wrath on enemies and mercy on His people.

questions.question: How does Psalms 79 instruct believers to respond to enemies who have wronged them?
options: Trust God to render their reproach sevenfold into their bosom.
Seek immediate personal revenge.
Ignore the wrongs and pretend they did not happen.
Join with enemies to avoid conflict.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to render their reproach sevenfold into their bosom.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 asks God to repay neighbors sevenfold for their reproach, showing reliance on God’s justice rather than personal retaliation. This teaches believers to leave vengeance to God while maintaining trust and patience. Verses 5 and 10 also emphasize God’s righteous anger and vindication.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 79, God’s jealousy burns like fire forever without end.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:5 questions how long God’s anger and jealousy will last, implying that His wrath is not eternal and that there is hope for His mercy. The psalm pleads for God’s tender mercies to come swiftly, indicating His anger is not without end.

questions.question: When facing discouragement from persecution, what biblical truth about God's power and protection does Psalms 79 teach?
options: God’s greatness preserves even those appointed to die.
Persecution is a sign of God’s rejection.
Human strength alone can overcome persecution.
God abandons those who are imprisoned.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s greatness preserves even those appointed to die.
questions.explanation: Verse 11 prays that according to God’s power, He would preserve those appointed to die, showing God’s sustaining power even in dire circumstances. This encourages believers to trust God's protective and preserving power in persecution.

questions.question: How does Psalms 79 encourage believers to express gratitude and worship after experiencing God’s deliverance?
options: By giving thanks forever and showing forth His praise to all generations.
By remaining silent and private about God’s works.
By only thanking God once deliverance is complete.
By focusing on personal achievements rather than God.
questions.correctAnswer: By giving thanks forever and showing forth His praise to all generations.
questions.explanation: Verse 13 promises that God’s people will give thanks forever and proclaim His praise to all generations, emphasizing continual worship and gratitude as a response to His faithfulness. This is a model for believers to publicly honor God.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'O God, the heathen are come into thine _______; thy holy temple have they defiled.'
options: heritage
inheritance
kingdom
land
questions.correctAnswer: inheritance
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:1 states that the heathen have come into God's inheritance and defiled His holy temple, emphasizing the seriousness of the desecration. The word 'inheritance' is the exact term used in the verse.

questions.question: What does Psalms 79 reveal about God’s attitude toward the enemies who have not known Him?
options: God’s wrath is poured out upon the heathen and kingdoms that have not called upon His name.
God ignores those who do not know Him.
God blesses all kingdoms equally regardless of their knowledge of Him.
God desires peace without judgment for all nations.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s wrath is poured out upon the heathen and kingdoms that have not called upon His name.
questions.explanation: Verse 6 requests God to pour out His wrath on heathen and kingdoms that have not called upon His name, showing God’s justice against those who oppose Him. This highlights the consequences of rejecting God’s authority.

questions.question: How should believers respond when they see the suffering of God’s servants, based on Psalms 79?
options: Call on God to avenge the blood of His servants and make His presence known among the nations.
Ignore the suffering as a natural consequence of sin.
Seek revenge through personal means.
Doubt God’s existence and protection.
questions.correctAnswer: Call on God to avenge the blood of His servants and make His presence known among the nations.
questions.explanation: Verse 10 asks God to be known among the heathen by revenging the blood of His servants, encouraging believers to trust God for justice and witness. This teaches reliance on God’s righteous judgment and the importance of His glory.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 79 teaches that God’s people are described as sheep of His pasture who give thanks forever.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:13 refers to God’s people as the sheep of His pasture who will give thanks forever, illustrating their dependence on Him and continual gratitude. This metaphor highlights humility and trust in God’s care.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline can be learned from Psalms 79 about dealing with overwhelming sin and judgment?
options: Confess sins and ask God to purge them for His name’s sake.
Ignore sin and hope it resolves itself.
Blame others for one’s own sins.
Avoid prayer when feeling guilty.
questions.correctAnswer: Confess sins and ask God to purge them for His name’s sake.
questions.explanation: Verse 9 shows the psalmist asking God to deliver and purge away sins for His name’s glory, emphasizing confession and seeking cleansing as key to restoration. Verses 8 and 9 together teach humility and dependence on God’s mercy.

questions.question: According to Psalms 79, what should be the attitude of God’s people towards their neighbors who reproach them?
options: Trust God to repay their reproach sevenfold rather than retaliate personally.
Retaliate immediately to defend their honor.
Ignore the reproach and hold a grudge.
Become angry and refuse to forgive.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God to repay their reproach sevenfold rather than retaliate personally.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 teaches leaving vengeance to God, asking Him to render reproach sevenfold. This encourages believers to practice patience, forgiveness, and trust in God’s justice instead of personal revenge.

questions.question: What lesson about God’s justice and mercy can be drawn from Psalms 79:3-7?
options: God allows enemies to destroy His people but is petitioned to remember mercy and deliverance.
God is indifferent to the plight of His servants.
God punishes without hope for restoration.
God’s justice means immediate destruction of enemies without prayer.
questions.correctAnswer: God allows enemies to destroy His people but is petitioned to remember mercy and deliverance.
questions.explanation: Verses 3-7 describe the destruction and bloodshed caused by enemies, but verses 8-9 plead for mercy and help. This shows the balance of God’s justice in allowing discipline and His mercy in responding to repentance and prayer.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 79 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 79.

questions.question: In Psalms 79:1, what significant event is described that reflects a historical attack on Jerusalem?
options: The heathen have come into God's inheritance and defiled the holy temple
The temple was rebuilt after exile
God promised peace to Jerusalem
The Israelites defeated their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen have come into God's inheritance and defiled the holy temple
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:1 describes how foreign nations invaded God's inheritance and defiled the holy temple, indicating a historical destruction of Jerusalem.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Psalms 79:2 when describing the fate of God's servants?
options: Metaphor
Hyperbole
Simile
Alliteration
questions.correctAnswer: Simile
questions.explanation: The verse uses similes comparing the dead bodies to food for birds and beasts, emphasizing the desecration (Psalms 79:2).

questions.question: How does the phrase 'Their blood have they shed like water round about Jerusalem' in Psalms 79:3 contribute to the psalm's theme?
options: It symbolizes the abundance and waste of innocent blood
It indicates a flood that covered Jerusalem
It refers to a ritual cleansing
It describes the irrigation system of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the abundance and waste of innocent blood
questions.explanation: The simile in Psalms 79:3 reflects the extensive shedding of innocent blood, emphasizing the destruction and injustice suffered.

questions.question: What does the psalmist express about Israel’s reputation among neighboring peoples in Psalms 79:4?
options: Israel has become a reproach and derision to neighbors
Israel is respected and honored
Israel is feared as a strong nation
Israel is unknown to its neighbors
questions.correctAnswer: Israel has become a reproach and derision to neighbors
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:4 states that Israel is mocked and scorned by surrounding peoples, highlighting their humiliation.

questions.question: What is the psalmist's urgent question posed to the Lord in Psalms 79:5?
options: How long will you be angry forever?
Will you bless your people soon?
When will the temple be rebuilt?
Why have you forgotten your covenant?
questions.correctAnswer: How long will you be angry forever?
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks in Psalms 79:5 about the duration of God's anger, showing a plea for mercy and restoration.

questions.question: In Psalms 79:6, who does the psalmist ask God to pour out wrath upon?
options: The heathen and kingdoms that have not known or called upon God's name
The people of Israel
The priests of the temple
The faithful worshippers
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen and kingdoms that have not known or called upon God's name
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:6 specifically calls for God's wrath against those who do not know Him or call upon His name.

questions.question: What historical context does the phrase 'For they have devoured Jacob' in Psalms 79:7 allude to?
options: The destruction of Israel by foreign invaders
The Exodus from Egypt
The reign of King David
The building of the first temple
questions.correctAnswer: The destruction of Israel by foreign invaders
questions.explanation: The phrase refers to the devastation caused by enemies against Israel (Jacob), as seen in Psalms 79:7, reflecting a period of foreign conquest.

questions.question: How does the psalmist appeal to God's mercy in Psalms 79:8?
options: By asking God to remember not former iniquities and to speedily help because they are brought low
By demanding immediate justice without forgiveness
By offering sacrifices for atonement
By promising to rebuild the temple
questions.correctAnswer: By asking God to remember not former iniquities and to speedily help because they are brought low
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:8 expresses a plea for God's tender mercies to quickly intervene, acknowledging their low state and seeking forgiveness.

questions.question: In what way does Psalms 79:9 connect the themes of salvation and God's glory?
options: The psalmist asks God to help for the glory of His name and to purge sins
Salvation is requested without mention of God's name
The psalmist offers personal glory in exchange for help
The verse focuses solely on physical deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: The psalmist asks God to help for the glory of His name and to purge sins
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:9 links deliverance and forgiveness to God's reputation and glory, showing that salvation honors God's name.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 79:10 expresses a concern about the heathen mocking Israel’s God because of the suffering of His servants.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse questions why the heathen would ask 'Where is their God?' highlighting concern for God's honor amid suffering (Psalms 79:10).

questions.question: Which concept in Psalms 79:11 reflects a deep trust in God's power to preserve life even in dire circumstances?
options: Preserving those appointed to die according to God's greatness
Calling for immediate punishment
Ignoring the plight of prisoners
Exalting human strength over divine power
questions.correctAnswer: Preserving those appointed to die according to God's greatness
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:11 expresses a plea for God to preserve prisoners, showing trust in His mighty power over life and death.

questions.question: In Psalms 79:12, what does the psalmist request God to render to their neighbors?
options: Sevenfold their reproach
Blessings and peace
Forgiveness and mercy
Gold and silver
questions.correctAnswer: Sevenfold their reproach
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks God to repay neighbors seven times for the reproach they caused to God (Psalms 79:12), indicating a call for divine justice.

questions.question: What imagery is used in Psalms 79:13 to describe the people of God and their relationship to Him?
options: Sheep of God's pasture giving thanks forever
Builders of the temple
Warriors fighting enemies
Scribes writing the law
questions.correctAnswer: Sheep of God's pasture giving thanks forever
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:13 uses pastoral imagery portraying God's people as sheep cared for by a shepherd, emphasizing dependence and gratitude.

questions.question: Which theme in Psalms 79 is foreshadowed by the plea for purging sins and deliverance in Psalms 79:9, later fulfilled in the New Testament?
options: Messianic atonement through Christ's sacrifice
The establishment of the Davidic kingdom
The building of the second temple
The conquest of Canaan
questions.correctAnswer: Messianic atonement through Christ's sacrifice
questions.explanation: The call for sin purging and deliverance anticipates the ultimate atonement fulfilled in Christ as seen throughout the New Testament, relating to Psalms 79:9.

questions.question: How does the historical-cultural context of ancient Near Eastern warfare enhance understanding of Psalms 79:2-3?
options: Desecration of bodies was a common way to shame defeated peoples
Burial of enemies was customary and honorable
Captives were usually integrated peacefully
Wars were fought only for land and not religious reasons
questions.correctAnswer: Desecration of bodies was a common way to shame defeated peoples
questions.explanation: The text's reference to dead bodies left for birds and beasts aligns with ancient Near Eastern practices of dishonoring enemies by denying burial (Psalms 79:2-3).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 79 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 79 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 79:1, what have the heathen done to God's inheritance?
options: They have defiled the holy temple and laid Jerusalem on heaps
They have built new altars for idols
They have respected the temple but taken the treasures
They have praised the God of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They have defiled the holy temple and laid Jerusalem on heaps
questions.explanation: Psalms 79:1 states that the heathen came into God's inheritance, defiled the holy temple, and laid Jerusalem on heaps, indicating a severe desecration and destruction. This theme of temple defilement is consistent with Jeremiah 7:30-31, Daniel 9:26, and Revelation 11:1-2, revealing the gravity of sin against God's dwelling place.

questions.question: What does Psalms 79:2 say has been done to the dead bodies of God's servants?
options: Given to be meat unto the fowls of the heaven and the flesh unto beasts of the earth
Buried with honor in the city gates
Taken captive and enslaved
Burned in a holy fire
questions.correctAnswer: Given to be meat unto the fowls of the heaven and the flesh unto beasts of the earth
questions.explanation: Verse 2 describes the dishonor and defilement of the bodies of God's servants, emphasizing the extent of the judgment and suffering. This reflects the consequences of sin and divine judgment found also in Ezekiel 39:17-20, 1 Kings 14:11, and Matthew 24:28, where bodies are left exposed as a sign of God's judgment.

questions.question: In Psalms 79:3, how is the blood of the slain described?
options: Shed like water round about Jerusalem with none to bury them
Collected in vessels for sacrifice
Hidden beneath the altar
Mixed with the harvest grain
questions.correctAnswer: Shed like water round about Jerusalem with none to bury them
questions.explanation: The verse vividly describes the abundance of bloodshed and the neglect to bury the dead, symbolizing the devastation and abandonment experienced. Similar imagery is seen in Lamentations 2:3, Ezekiel 24:7, and Hebrews 12:24, illustrating the consequences of sin and the need for redemption.

questions.question: According to Psalms 79:4, how have Israel's neighbors viewed them?
options: As a reproach, scorn, and derision
As a powerful and blessed nation
As peaceful and wise neighbors
As invincible warriors
questions.correctAnswer: As a reproach, scorn, and derision
questions.explanation: The psalmist laments that Israel has become a disgrace and object of mockery to surrounding peoples, reflecting the consequences of their suffering and exile. This theme appears in Isaiah 49:7, Jeremiah 25:9, and Romans 15:3, highlighting the scorn that often accompanies divine discipline.

questions.question: What is the psalmist's plea regarding God's anger in Psalms 79:5?
options: How long will the Lord be angry forever? Will His jealousy burn like fire?
Let the Lord's anger continue without end
God should ignore the people's sins
God should remain silent and inactive
questions.correctAnswer: How long will the Lord be angry forever? Will His jealousy burn like fire?
questions.explanation: The question expresses a desire for God's wrath to cease, acknowledging His jealousy and righteous anger against sin. This plea for mercy amid divine judgment is echoed in Exodus 34:6-7, Nahum 1:2, and Romans 2:4, emphasizing God's holiness balanced with compassion.

questions.question: In Psalms 79:6, upon whom does the psalmist ask God to pour out His wrath?
options: The heathen that have not known God and kingdoms that have not called upon His name
The people of Israel who have sinned
The prophets who mislead the people
The priests who defiled the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The heathen that have not known God and kingdoms that have not called upon His name
questions.explanation: The psalmist asks for God's judgment on those who are ignorant of Him and reject His name, highlighting the holiness of God and His justice against sin and idolatry. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 32:21, Romans 1:18-21, and Revelation 6:10, which speak of God's righteous wrath on the nations.

questions.question: What do the enemies do to Jacob in Psalms 79:7?
options: They have devoured Jacob and laid waste his dwelling place
They have blessed Jacob and restored his land
They have ignored Jacob completely
They have become servants to Jacob
questions.correctAnswer: They have devoured Jacob and laid waste his dwelling place
questions.explanation: This verse metaphorically describes the destruction of Israel by enemies, reflecting the consequences of rebellion and divine discipline. Similar language is found in Hosea 4:1-3, Isaiah 10:6, and Matthew 21:38, emphasizing God's sovereign judgment on sin.

questions.question: What does the psalmist ask God to remember or not remember in Psalms 79:8?
options: Do not remember former iniquities, but let tender mercies speedily prevent us
Remember all our sins to punish us
Forget us entirely as a people
Remember only the sins of others
questions.correctAnswer: Do not remember former iniquities, but let tender mercies speedily prevent us
questions.explanation: The plea for mercy asks God to overlook past sins and act with compassion quickly, highlighting the theme of forgiveness and restoration. This echoes Psalm 103:12, Isaiah 43:25, and 2 Corinthians 5:19, where God’s mercy triumphs over judgment.

questions.question: In Psalms 79:9, for what purpose does the psalmist ask God to help and deliver His people?
options: For the glory of His name and to purge away their sins
To increase their wealth and power
To overthrow all their enemies without repentance
To remain silent and inactive
questions.correctAnswer: For the glory of His name and to purge away their sins
questions.explanation: The psalmist appeals for salvation linked to God's holiness and glory, emphasizing that deliverance is not only for the people’s sake but to uphold God's name. Similar motifs appear in Isaiah 48:9-11, Ezekiel 36:22-23, and John 12:28, underscoring God's purpose in salvation.

questions.question: What concern does the psalmist raise in Psalms 79:10 about the heathen?
options: That they might say, 'Where is their God?'
That they will worship the true God
That they will ally with Israel
That they will repent immediately
questions.correctAnswer: That they might say, 'Where is their God?'
questions.explanation: The concern is that the nations will mock God’s power and presence due to Israel’s suffering, challenging the believer’s confidence. This question appears in Exodus 17:7, Habakkuk 1:11, and John 20:29, where faith is tested by apparent divine silence or defeat.

questions.question: According to Psalms 79:11, what does the psalmist ask God to do with the sighing of the prisoner?
options: Let it come before God and preserve those appointed to die
Ignore it completely
Punish them more severely
Turn it into joy without change
questions.correctAnswer: Let it come before God and preserve those appointed to die
questions.explanation: The psalmist petitions God to hear the cries of the oppressed and exercise His power to save even those facing death. This reflects God's attentiveness to suffering found in Psalm 34:18, Isaiah 61:1, and Romans 8:38-39.

questions.question: In Psalms 79:12, what does the psalmist ask God to render to their neighbors?
options: Sevenfold their reproach into their bosom
A blessing and peace
Forgiveness and mercy
Silence and forgetfulness
questions.correctAnswer: Sevenfold their reproach into their bosom
questions.explanation: This verse calls for just recompense for the insults and injuries inflicted by enemies, reflecting the biblical principle of divine justice. The sevenfold punishment motif appears in Proverbs 6:31, Jeremiah 15:20, and Romans 12:19, affirming God’s role as righteous judge.

questions.question: What commitment do the people make in Psalms 79:13?
options: To give thanks forever and show forth God's praise to all generations
To seek revenge against their enemies
To rebuild the temple without God's help
To abandon their faith
questions.correctAnswer: To give thanks forever and show forth God's praise to all generations
questions.explanation: The psalm closes with a vow of perpetual gratitude and praise, highlighting the covenantal relationship between God and His people. This commitment aligns with Psalm 100:4, Isaiah 12:4-5, and Hebrews 13:15, emphasizing worship as a response to salvation.

questions.question: What attribute of God is most emphasized in Psalms 79:5-6 regarding His response to sin and the heathen?
options: His jealous and wrathful justice against sin
His indifference to human affairs
His passive acceptance of evil
His forgetfulness
questions.correctAnswer: His jealous and wrathful justice against sin
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 emphasize God's jealousy and wrath poured out on those who reject Him, reflecting His holiness and justice. This attribute is consistent with Exodus 20:5, Nahum 1:2-3, Romans 1:18, and Revelation 19:11, underscoring God's intolerance for sin.

questions.question: How does Psalms 79 express the need for atonement and cleansing in relation to sin?
options: By asking God to deliver and purge away their sins for His name's sake (79:9)
By denying the existence of sin
By suggesting that human effort alone can remove sin
By ignoring sin and focusing on prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: By asking God to deliver and purge away their sins for His name's sake (79:9)
questions.explanation: The plea for deliverance and purification in verse 9 highlights the necessity of divine atonement, reflecting the doctrine of salvation by God's grace. This is echoed in Leviticus 16:30, Psalm 51:7, Isaiah 1:18, and 1 John 1:9.
